title: How can technology be improved in developing countries like Nigeria? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’ve been contemplating something similar to this question for a long, long while now and the answer I came up with is honestly dreadfully simple. Change the laws. Nigeria’s issues aren’t really a lack of talent, financing, or even corruption honestly in my opinion, although I won’t deny none of that really helps. Their problems are mostly bureaucratic. Nigeria makes it very hard for large entrepreneurial endeavors to be undertaken by its citizens let alone individual foreigners. Let’s take housing for example. In Nigeria, clear cut land ownership isn’t something you can just pick up from some random property seller and purchase on the fly like we do in the US and Foreign land ownership isn’t even a thing there. It’s not allowed. As a potential investor, this fact alone is a huge detractor for me. What they do however, is allow people to basically lease the land for a term of say 99 years. That’s not even the worst of it though, when you do “purchase” property you have to get approval from the local leaders. In Lagos this means getting approval from the Governor in addition to other registration requirements. The same essentially applies to the tech industry. Local laws make it difficult to build large infrastructure projects like railways and power grids. It’s gotten so bad that even their own government has issues funding projects and needs other more wealthier nations to do it for them. I’ve attached an article that basically sums this up. While governance is listed as number three I feel that it’s the biggest issue preventing the first two. 5 Major Challenges Of Doing Business In Nigeria (2019)
